Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2008 06:24PM judyr wrote: I ate a lot of egg drop soup and chicken noodle soup. Both were easy to get at a chinese takeout and we got the chicken noodle soup at Costco. I was cold all the time so warm foods were good for me.  Other than that I didn't eat much either. I was pregnant at the time and I lost some weight over the chemo time as well. Hang in there, you will find a few standbys that appeal to you........... Judy
Posts.Title: Veterans, help! Appetite changes Misty1 Drea

Posts.Content: judyr wrote: I just posted this in the young womens forum, but I thought someone might see it more quickly if I posted it on this forum as well. I got a call from my girlfriend whose 16 year old daughter had a mass removed from her breast on Monday. She said the surgeon called here and said the pathology shows a phyllodes tumor that is borderline benign/ intermediate. He wants them to come in first thing in the morning and talk more. Anna is not going to be home till later this eve. and they don't know what to tell her. The whole procedure was very hard. I immediately went to breast cancer .org for info but found nothing on this. So, my questions are what do you tell her and what the heck is this. Is there a better information source that I can pass on to her mom? Thank you all! IDC and DCIS 9/15/06 Stage I Grade 3 ER+PR+ HER2- Found when 9 weeks pregnant Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Need information on Phllodes tumor for 16 year old! judyr roseg

Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2009 11:25PM judyr wrote: Thank you for your reply's.  She is such a sweet girl. It looks like they are going to do a wide excision so that they can get clear margins, not a mastectomy but almost as she is small and the tumor was 4 cm. They did see an oncologist as the tumor was intermediate grade ( it's catagoried benign, intermediate or malignant.)   If anyone has any further information, I would love to hear it and I will pass it on. Thank you! Judy

Posts.Title: My story PeaceCat judyr

Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2008 11:12PM judyr wrote: Hi Joy, There is a good explination of pathology reports on the main website breastcacer.org. I would go there first and start reading. The important things are the size (1.9mm is good and small), the grade of the cancer cells ( from 1-3 so 2 is better than 3!) and the mitotic rate is how fast the cells are reproducing (intermediate is not too bad either). There is much more but like peeling an onion you will process the information layer by layer. It really stinks to have to make that choice. It would be easier to just be told this is what you need............Don't hesitate to get a second opinion. Good luck! Judy

Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2007 12:18AM judyr wrote: Hi TinaLee, Mine was like a mack truck ran over my chest. It was very uncomfortable. It did get better but it took a while. I would guard it against my kids bumping it with their heads when they sat in my lap. Months later I definately knew it was there but it didn't hurt and now(one year later) I forget it's there. I don't mean to make it sound bad, it was very doable but it is normal I think for it to hurt..... blessings, Judy
